messages: 4d05dc3c4352ebe7593b536f2078cfe9 (00:01): http://blog.chromium.org/2010/09/webp-new-image-format-for-web.html
4d05dc3c4352ebe7593b536f2078cfe9 (00:02): improving 65% of a page by 39% seems pretty good to me
4d05dc3c4352ebe7593b536f2078cfe9 (00:03): plus transparency in a future update
4d05dc3c4352ebe7593b536f2078cfe9 (00:04): this part seems pretty interesting
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (00:06): oh boy oh boy
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (00:10): i'm disappointed that they didn't add transparency right away
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (00:10): the web really needs some lossy true color image format with support for transparency
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (00:10): if it's something photo based, png32 is just too f-ing huge
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:11): 4d05dc3c4352ebe7593b536f2078cfe9: They say they saved an average 39% on a collection of JPEG/PNG/GIF images without "perceptibly" affecting quality
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:12): which seems a pretty useless number if I'm interpreting it right
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:12): because one person might have a photo saved as a 5MB PNG and they'd get huge compression improvements by encoding even as plain old JPEG
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (00:13): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c, check the gallery: http://code.google.com/speed/webp/gallery.html
4d05dc3c4352ebe7593b536f2078cfe9 (00:13): yes, that only says "if everyone uses webp instead of what they're doing now, we'll save 39%"

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:14): It'd be more useful if they did comparisons against JPEG re-encoding with equivalent quality loss, and against the dozens of other JPEG-but-slighty-better formats that exist
4d05dc3c4352ebe7593b536f2078cfe9 (00:15): they did the first one
3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653 (00:16): is there a list of SVG tests someplace?
3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653 (00:16): that wants tests added?
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (00:16): ye, a comparison with jp2 and jpg xr would have ben nice
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (00:17): well, in about 10 years we can use jp2 :>
4d05dc3c4352ebe7593b536f2078cfe9 (00:17): the link cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb posted
3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653 (00:17): safari apparently currently supports marker-start, marker-mid, marker-end, but not marker as attributes on paths

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:19): 4d05dc3c4352ebe7593b536f2078cfe9: That says they're comparing against JPEG originals (which might have stupid compression settings), not against re-encoded JPEGs

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:21): 4d05dc3c4352ebe7593b536f2078cfe9: e.g. they claim 76% improvement on http://code.google.com/speed/webp/images/2.jpg, but if I just save it as a JPEG in Gimp then I can get 76% improvement without it looking much different
3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653 (00:23): 4d05dc3c4352ebe7593b536f2078cfe9, ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: the webp images seem to have their color profiles stripped?
3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653 (00:24): espadrine: JP2 is used a lot by people archiving very large images
3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653 (00:24): it's just not used by consumer-facing web apps
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:25): (The fact you can get a big improvement by just recompressing as marginally lower quality JPEG indicates that most people don't care about image size anyway)
3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653 (00:25): decoders for JPEG 2000 are much much slower than decoders for JPEG
3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653 (00:26): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: or it indicates that grabbing the originals uploaded to wikipedia is a bad way to find compressed images
3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653 (00:26): I believe the wikipedia thumbnails are reasonably compressed. the originals should be as high quality as possible IMO
3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653 (00:27): because you never know what someone might want to do with them, and they won't be served to article page viewers
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:27): ah, WebP is out
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:27): and my inbox is full of bugmail yay
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:28): Are there better benchmarks of WebP anywhere that I'm missing?
3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653 (00:28): also, if google wants to use the lena image, they should just ask playboy; the magazine hasn't had any problem in the past with its use
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:29): "<video> element needs to support some form of parental control solution" whoa
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:29): lets boil the ocean
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (00:29): the internet is AO rated
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:29): Better add parental controls to <img> first
3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653 (00:30): using webp for images seems to me like a really stupid thing to be pushing
3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653 (00:30): I guess they want to hype the video format?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:30): John Foliot is also asking for DRM
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:31): fun times
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:31): http://code.google.com/speed/webp/docs/c_study.html - ah, that has more data
3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653 (00:32): yeah, their jpeg 2000 numbers seem pretty sketchy
3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653 (00:33): is there any evidence that PSNR is a good metric for "human-detectable degradation"
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:33): Seems the average improvement over (Re-)JPEG is more like 20%
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:34): Are WebP and/or JPEG and/or JPEG2K optimised for PSNR?
3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653 (00:34): I'd be very interested to see what the JPEG 2000 inventors have to say about this study
3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653 (00:34): also, they took existing jpeg images to convert, it looks like?
3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653 (00:35): of arbitrary provenance
3b14b636129945831fcfcc7294686653 (00:35): some of those might be ickily compressed with lots of artifacts aligned with jpeg block boundaries
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:43): http://code.google.com/speed/webp/index.html - "Did you know? WebP is pronounced "weppy"." - no it's not, it's pronounced "web pee"
